CAPTION: 1566 IN RE: Western States Wholesale Natural Gas Antitrust Litigation
COMMENTS_OLD: Stipulated order
Notes: There are a lot of appointments in this MDL as plaintiffs got classes certified and class counsel appointments for the purposes of settlements with 1-2 defendants at a time. So there are lots of appointments, but they are generally the same firms appointed to represent the same classes, just for the purposes of settlement with a different defendant. The court also issued separate orders for preliminary and final approval of each settlement.

CAPTION: 2406 IN RE: Blue Cross Blue Shield Antitrust Litigation
COMMENTS_OLD: Based on magistrate R&R. Detailed and weird leadership structure. '"The Special Master interviewed all persons seeking an appointment"
Notes: This MDL has an absurdly large leadership team. Over 100 attorneys are appointed to various positions.

CAPTION: 2151 IN RE: Toyota Motor Corp. Unintended Acceleration Marketing, Sales Practices, and Products Liability Litigation
COMMENTS_OLD: Contested; lots of applications; really bonkers structure -- good example of ad hocery
Notes: After hearing concerns from counsel that the leadership structure, over time, would need to be replenished annually as lawyers took on other projects, Judge Seylna ordered lawyers to reapply for leadership annually. However, with the exception of only one or two lawyers--and the resolution of a class action--the lawyers on leadership remained mostly the same. Another notable feature of the litigation was that both plaintiff and defense counsel urged the MDL judge to create a larger leadership structure, particularly for the discovery involved in automotive cases. Defense attorneys observed that experienced lawyers in such cases were valuable to work with. Judge Seylna ultimately allowed the plaintiffs to enlarge the size of leadership.

CAPTION: 2158 IN RE: Zimmer Durom Hip Cup Products Liability Litigation
COMMENTS_OLD: Orders rolling production of medical records before motion practice in anticipation of mediation
Notes:
Interesting litigation. The initial case management order sets up a mandatory mediation protocol which appears to have been used to resolve all the claims. After that, all the orders are skirmishes over common benefit fees, particularly the extent to which state court plaintiffs have to kick in to pay the MDL leaders' fees. It ends with a September 2018 order awarding about $2M, mainly to Seeger Weiss and Waters & Kraus 

--ASZ Note: It might be helpful to compare the Zimmer litigation structure to other hip implant cases, including Striker and Dupuy. Striker was resolved very similarly. So, it would be helpful to know if we're seeing the same structure proposed by the same kinds of plaintiff attorneys.

DN 2/25: Confirmed that no leadership orders entered after Doc No. 9. Lots of orders reducing common benefit fees at the end of the litigaiton.
